p:
Characterization of the CWWA and WWA was carried out using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) to determine the wide range of surface topography and composition illustrated in Fig. 1. Fourier transforms infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) to determine the chemical bonds and the angle of resolution within the wavelength band displayed in Fig. 2. The spectra give rise to the shape of the CWWA and WWA as an individual molecular pattern that can be used to screen and scan the powders for different transmittances as explained in Table 2. X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) was used to quantitative and qualitatively estimated the elemental compositions in the sample. BET isothermal adsorption to determine the surface area, the pore volume, and the total basic density of the powder, while Hammett indicator was used to determine the basic strength of the CWWA displayed in Table 3.Fig. 1
SEM analysis of the WWA.Fig 1Fig. 2
FTIR spectral of CWWA.Fig 2Table 2
